Award.AwardTitle: Cooperative Pulse Waveforms in Quadrupolar NMR
Award.AbstractNarration:
CHE-1412064: Cooperative Pulse Waveforms in Quadrupolar NMR

In this project funded by the Chemical Measurements and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Alexej Jerschow of New York University is developing new nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy techniques for the efficient measurement and characterization of sodium in materials or tissues. These techniques could eventually be used in magnetic resonance imaging applications, and in materials characterization techniques, quality control, and diagnostics for cancer. This project focuses on the design of new radiofrequency waveforms, designed by optimal control theory techniques, to obtain sensitivity enhancements in the measurements of sodium nuclei, as well as, to increase the specificity of such techniques with respect to the characterization of these nuclei in different environments.

In a broader context, Professor Jerschow also works on the development of spectroscopic and imaging techniques in the arts conservation field, in collaboration with Professor Eleonora Del Federico and Professor Cindie Kehlet from Pratt Institute. This activity allows to foster collaborations between conservators, arts students, and chemistry students and researchers in addressing problems of arts conservation science and to reach out to a diverse student population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NMR spectroscopy is a vital research tool in the fields of Chemistry, Materials Sciences, and Medicine, and has a direct link to MRI methods used in medicine. Signal sensitivity is often a major limiting factor in many experiments. In MRI imaging, for example, higher sensitivity would allow patient scans to become shorter, thus enhancing patient comfort. The project set out to develop optimized signal excitation and manipulation techniques based on pulse sequence and waveform generation. During the project, the PI developed new types of experiments for signal enhancement, specifically for the ability to measure sodium. In physiological environments, sodium can exist in a number of different motional regimes, which can be differentiated with the use of pulse sequences designed in part under this award. In other research areas, such as materials sciences, the work is of relevance as well. Under this award, the PI also led efforts to determine the behavior of sodium ions in porous structures, such as natural sandstones. This work is of relevance for determining the nature of oil and water reservoirs.

In a broader context, the project produced techniques for obtaining NMR and MRI signals with higher sensitivity and selectivity for other nuclei as well. Areas of application included branching out into new areas of research, including the analysis of batteries and battery materials via the measurement of lithium ions. 7Li is a nucleus similar to 23Na, and thus some of the developed results were of relevance in this area as well. The measurement and characterization of oxygen nuclei in water allowed the PI to characterized previously unknown properties of water at its temperature of maximum density. Further work included the study and optimal excitation of long-lived signals, and the study of tablet disintegrants.

The project also involved a collaboration with Pratt Institute, whereby both science and arts researchers collaborates on applying the tools of Chemistry to studying problems of Arts Conservation.
